clean_story:
"Earth’s stand-ins. Alien terrain, studied here. "

Planetary analog sites are Earth locations that mimic conditions on other planets or moons—geology, climate, or chemistry—used to test rovers, suits, and theories without leaving home.

They’re the proving grounds for space exploration.

NASA’s Devon Island in the Arctic—barren, cold, and cratered—mirrors Mars so closely that rovers like Haughton-Mars Project’s prototypes train there.

In Chile’s Atacama Desert, the driest place on Earth, scientists hunt for extremophiles in salt flats to model life’s potential on Europa.

Tools like LIBS spectrometers (used on Perseverance) first scanned Atacama’s soils to refine Martian mineral detection.

Even underwater: Florida’s Aquarius Reef Base simulates lunar gravity for astronaut training.

Precision matters—wrong soil pH or wind patterns can skew a decade of research.

Three related subjects are extremophile survival, in-situ resource use, and terrain-relative navigation.
